newsitem.title: FRANCE: French workers detain Giat bosses in jobs protest.
newsitem.headline: French workers detain Giat bosses in jobs protest.

text.p: Eleven executives of state arms maker Giat-Industries were being held hostage on Tuesday for a second day at a plant in southwest France by workers protesting against job cuts.
The executives, contacted overnight by colleagues, said there had been no violence.
The workers are angry over Giat's plans to cut 595 jobs out of a total of 1,800 at the Tarbes production site as part of a company-wide restructuring plan.

Jean-Claude Daroque, representative of the communist-led CGT union at the plant, said on Monday the hostage-taking would continue until "there are more serious discussions on this plan for massive layoffs".
The workers voted by 70 percent on Tuesday to continue their occupation. A company spokesman was not immediately available for comment.

The company, best known for its Leclerc tanks, is planning to cut a total of 2,569 out of 12,000 jobs as part of its restructuring aimed at focusing on its core business of tanks, armoured vehicles and ammunitions.
The move is part of a larger reform of the French defence industry under conservative President Jacques Chirac.
Hit by a drop in orders since the end of the Cold War, Giat reported a huge net loss of 10 billion French francs ($1.93 billion) for 1995.
Earlier this month, workers at the same Tarbes plant occupied administrative offices as part of a part of a national strike to protest the restructuring plan.
